content.description: This route is a grunter.  The first crux is right off the ground and a second about 10 feet from the top.  The moves aren't classic, but will make you think.  The first crux is technical, while the higher crux requires a bit of power.  Once you find the start is is pretty hard to get off route.
content.protection: Top rope only.  Not safely leadable.
content.location: This route starts about 5 feet right of Heatwave, under a small triangular roof.

content.description:
Text taken from "RCM&W,"-Mike Farris. 

  On the south side of the buttress is a right facing corner.  Climb the face to the right, with the crux just off the ground.
content.protection: Hand sized and smaller nuts/hexes should do it.  Standard top rope with some stoppers and slinging the boulder.
content.location: South Side of Indian head buttress.

content.description: Too short but fun movements.  Easily protectable
content.protection: Easy top rope or for lead 2.5 inches down to .5
content.location: Just off the trail on your way to the other Indian head climbs.  Off the Echo Valley trail

content.description: Follow the crack up and to the left.  Continue up and to the right to the top.  This route takes gear well at the bottom but pro is a little thin at the top, but still protects adequately.  I thought the crux was figuring out the top.
content.protection: Standard rack.  Standard top rope set up.
content.location: This route is to the right of Air Conditioned.  Look for a crack that curves up and left.

content.description:
Keeping your top rope anchors the same as Indian Head, flip your rope around the corner towards Air Conditioned. This is a straight up rock face with horizontal cracks. There is a nice grab on the corner. Please be kind to the moss, lichen and ferns. You don’t need to bother them to climb this route

 If you play Marco Polo with the climbers on the Minnesota Strip, you might be asked on a date.
content.protection: Anchor around big boulders, same as Indian Head.
content.location: Between Indian Head and Air Conditioned. Use same anchor as Indian Head.

content.description: Follow the air conditioned crack (thin hands; crux) up to a ledge.  Continue on somewhat broken rock to the top.  A fun lead that takes good gear.  The broken rock towards the top is a little suspect, but i felt pretty good about all my placements there.
content.protection: Standard rack.  A few extra thin hands sized pieces if you really want to sew up the bottom crack.  Standard top rope setup, maybe a little extra webbing, I remember the placements being a bit spaced out.
content.location: From the Indian Head feauture continue left around the rock scrambling to the based of the crack.

content.description: A good place to go on a sunny day.  There is only a small cluster of routes here but in my opinion its well worth the trip.  The crag is located up from the river in a wooded area.  If you are unfortunate enough to find the climbs you wanted to do occupied you continue down the trail and reach Sentinel Area.
